marginalia.translation: The essential preparation for civil elocution. 1) The Aula ciuilis Conuersationis, which is the golden foundation of an urban speech; and the actual royal profession of princely eloquence. 2) John Eliot's dialogues on civil commerce [the Ortho-epia gallica] 3) Stefano Guazzo, book 4 [of 'The civil conservation'], of 'a civil banquet'. 4) Roger Ascham's 'Discourse' of Charles V's political negotations. Singular, most speedily by heart. It is even useful to have Heywood's most familiar 5) general proverbs and his own epigrams. 6) Likewise Du Bartas' brightest 'triumph of the French king': in which nothing more lively can be read. With the delicate inner parts of all in Eunapius' 'Lives'. 7, 8) (and with Domenichi's witticisms. These are the shortest and most necessary. Although it is free of longer and fuller variety. Before all things I prefer the 9, 10) 'Arcadia of the Countess' and the 'heroic sayings and deeds of Gargantua'. I even add to the variety of discourses, 11) the Apology of Herodotus, 12) and Manlius' common places. 13) With the most useful and sweetest strategies of Marcantonio Gandino. And others; a living praxis demonstrates the most fruitful things of the most excellent actors in the world.
